title: In-Class Exercise 9: Geographically-weighted Random Forest methods
section: Preparing the HDB resale data for predictive analysis
text:
Preparing the HDB resale data for predictive analysis

Splitting the data into training and testing datasets


Reveal Code
set.seed(1234)

resale_split <- initial_split(rs_sf, prop = 5/10)

train_sf <- training(resale_split)
test_sf <- testing(resale_split)




Obtaining the data frame object from the HDB dataset


Reveal Code
train_df <- train_sf %>% 
  st_drop_geometry() %>% 
  as.data.frame()

test_df <- test_sf %>% 
  st_drop_geometry() %>% 
  as.data.frame()

title: In-Class Exercise 9: Geographically-weighted Random Forest methods
text:
Computing the correlation matrix


Reveal Code
rs_df <- rs_sf %>% 
  st_drop_geometry() %>% 
  as.data.frame()

ggcorrmat(rs_df[, 2:17])

title: In-Class Exercise 9: Geographically-weighted Random Forest methods
section: Building a multivariate linear non-spatial regression model
text:
Building a multivariate linear non-spatial regression model


Reveal Code
rs_mlr <- lm(RESALE_PRICE ~ FLOOR_AREA_SQM +
                  STOREY_ORDER + REMAINING_LEASE_MTHS +
                  PROX_CBD + PROX_ELDERLYCARE + + PROX_CHAS + PROX_HAWKER +
                  PROX_MRT + PROX_PARK + PROX_GOOD_PRISCH + PROX_MALL + 
                  PROX_SUPERMARKET + WITHIN_350M_KINDERGARTEN +
                  WITHIN_350M_CHILDCARE + WITHIN_350M_BUS +
                  WITHIN_1KM_PRISCH,
                data= train_df)

tbl_regression(rs_mlr, intercept = TRUE)

Revising the regression model

Dropping the insignificant variables from the testing & training datasets


Reveal Code
train_df <- train_df %>% 
  select(-c(PROX_CHAS))

test_df <- test_df %>% 
  select(-c(PROX_CHAS))

train_sf <- train_sf %>% 
  select(-c(PROX_CHAS))

test_sf <- test_sf %>% 
  select(-c(PROX_CHAS))

Reveal Code
rpart.plot(rs_rp)











Calibrating the random forest model


Reveal Code
rs_rf <- ranger(RESALE_PRICE ~ FLOOR_AREA_SQM +
                  STOREY_ORDER + REMAINING_LEASE_MTHS +
                  PROX_CBD + PROX_ELDERLYCARE + PROX_HAWKER +
                  PROX_MRT + PROX_PARK + PROX_GOOD_PRISCH + PROX_MALL + 
                  PROX_SUPERMARKET + WITHIN_350M_KINDERGARTEN +
                  WITHIN_350M_CHILDCARE + WITHIN_350M_BUS +
                  WITHIN_1KM_PRISCH, 
                data= train_df, 
                importance ="impurity")

rs_rf


Ranger result

Call:
 ranger(RESALE_PRICE ~ FLOOR_AREA_SQM + STOREY_ORDER + REMAINING_LEASE_MTHS +      PROX_CBD + PROX_ELDERLYCARE + PROX_HAWKER + PROX_MRT + PROX_PARK +      PROX_GOOD_PRISCH + PROX_MALL + PROX_SUPERMARKET + WITHIN_350M_KINDERGARTEN +      WITHIN_350M_CHILDCARE + WITHIN_350M_BUS + WITHIN_1KM_PRISCH,      data = train_df, importance = "impurity")

R squared (OOB):                  0.9482457 




Extracting the variable importance values of the random forest model


Reveal Code
vi <- as.data.frame(rs_rf$variable.importance)
vi$variables <- rownames(vi)

vi <- vi %>% 
  rename(vi = "rs_rf$variable.importance")




Visualing the variable importance factors


Reveal Code
ggplot(data = vi, 
       aes(x = vi, y = reorder(variables, vi))) + 
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")











Building the geographically-weighted random forest model


Reveal Code
rs_gwrf <- grf(formula = RESALE_PRICE ~ FLOOR_AREA_SQM +
                  STOREY_ORDER + REMAINING_LEASE_MTHS +
                  PROX_CBD + PROX_ELDERLYCARE + PROX_HAWKER +
                  PROX_MRT + PROX_PARK + PROX_GOOD_PRISCH + PROX_MALL + 
                  PROX_SUPERMARKET + WITHIN_350M_KINDERGARTEN +
                  WITHIN_350M_CHILDCARE + WITHIN_350M_BUS +
                  WITHIN_1KM_PRISCH, 
               dframe = train_df, 
               bw = 55,
               kernel = "adaptive", 
               coords = coords_train, 
               geo.weighted = TRUE)

write_rds(rs_gwrf, "Data/Models/rs_gwrf.rds")




Reveal Code
rs_gwrf <- read_rds("Data/Models/rs_gwrf.rds")

title: In-Class Exercise 9: Geographically-weighted Random Forest methods
text:
Comparing the ML model’s performance


Reveal Code
test_df <- cbind(test_sf, coords_test) %>% 
  st_drop_geometry()



Testing the geographically-weighted random forest performance


Reveal Code
gwrf_pred <- predict.grf(rs_gwrf, 
                         test_df, 
                         x.var.name = "X",
                         y.var.name = "Y", 
                         local.w = 1,
                         global.w = 0)

write_rds(gwrf_pred, "Data/Models/rs_gwrf_pred.rds")




Reveal Code
gwrf_pred <- read_rds("Data/Models/rs_gwrf_pred.rds")




Reveal Code
test_pred <- test_df %>% 
  select(RESALE_PRICE) %>% 
  cbind(gwrf_pred)




Testing the non-geographically-weighted random forest performance


Reveal Code
rf_pred <- predict(rs_rf, test_df)




Reveal Code
rf_pred_df <- as.data.frame(rf_pred$predictions) %>% 
  rename(rf_pred = "rf_pred$predictions")




Reveal Code
test_pred <- cbind(test_pred, rf_pred_df)




Testing the multivariate linear regression performance


Reveal Code
mlr_pred <- predict(rs_mlr, test_df)




Reveal Code
mlr_pred_df <- as.data.frame(mlr_pred) %>% 
  rename(mlr_pred = "mlr_pred")




Reveal Code
test_pred <- cbind(test_pred, mlr_pred_df)




Comparing the models’ performances using RMSE


Reveal Code
mc <- test_pred %>% 
  pivot_longer(cols = c(2:4), 
               names_to = "models", 
               values_to = "predicted") %>% 
  group_by(models) %>% 
  yardstick::rmse(RESALE_PRICE, predicted)

mc


# A tibble: 3 × 4
  models    .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>     <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 gwrf_pred rmse    standard      28745.
2 mlr_pred  rmse    standard      61617.
3 rf_pred   rmse    standard      28388.




Visualising the models’ performance


Reveal Code
ggplot(data = test_pred, 
       aes(x = gwrf_pred, 
           y = RESALE_PRICE)) + 
  geom_point()









Reveal Code
ggplot(data = test_pred, 
       aes(x = mlr_pred, 
           y = RESALE_PRICE)) + 
  geom_point()









Reveal Code
ggplot(data = test_pred, 
       aes(x = rf_pred, 
           y = RESALE_PRICE)) + 
  geom_point()

Here, we compute the number of each ammenity found in each planning subzone of Singapore using st_intersects() and lengths() functions, and compile them into a single sf object using bind_cols().


Reveal Code
hawker_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, hawker_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

mrt_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, mrt_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

school_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, school_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

supermarket_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, supermarket_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

mall_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, mall_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

ammenities_area_sf <- sg_area_sf %>% 
  bind_cols(hawker_count = hawker_count, 
            mrt_count = mrt_count, 
            school_count = school_count,
            supermarket_count = supermarket_count,
            mall_count = mall_count)

In this section, we conduct an analysis into the clustering options that we have for our data set. This involves both the number of clusters to impose on the data set as well as how to assign the planning subzones of Singapore to each cluster.




Reveal Code
proxmat <- dist(cluster_vars, method = 'euclidean')
glimpse(proxmat)

 - attr(*, "method")= chr "euclidean"
 - attr(*, "call")= language dist(x = cluster_vars, method = "euclidean")







Reveal Code

plot(hclust_ward, cex = 0.6)

  agnes(cluster_vars, method = x)$ac
}

map_dbl(m, ac)

Reveal Code
set.seed(3414)

gap_stat <- clusGap(cluster_vars, 
                    FUN = hcut, 
                    nstart = 25, 
                    K.max = 10, 
                    B = 50)

print(gap_stat, method = "firstmax")

After computation of the Gap-statistics, we can visualise the results via the fviz_gap_stat() function. From the graph drawn, we could use either 8 or 10 clusters in our algorithm as they are quite similar in effectiveness in capturing the clustering patterns of ammenity options across Singapore. Lesser clusters like 7 or 5 might be possible but not optimal. For the rest of this analysis, 8 shall be used as it is more parsimonious than 10 whilst having an indistinguishable Gap statistic.


Reveal Code
fviz_gap_stat(gap_stat)














In this section, we shall outline how the UI design will work. The main selectable variable here will be the number of clusters used in the clustering algorithm. For the purpose of this demonstration, 8 shall be the default as it is the optimal number computed using Gap-statistics as a measure. Other selectables to be included are the parts of Singapore to be analysed, the used of planning zone types (i.e. subzone, region etc.) and the types of ammenities to be investigated.


Here we will produce the cluster dendrogram with each cluster highlighted based on the requested number of clusters selected from above.


Reveal Code
plot(hclust_ward, cex = 0.6)

rect.hclust(hclust_ward, 
            k = 10, 
            border = 2:5)












Like above, the following UI will demonstrate how the clustering mechanism works based on a requested number of clusters selected. Additionally, options to apply different standardisation options will be included. Here, standardisation via Z-score is used for the demonstration.


Reveal Code
ammenities_mat <- data.matrix(ammenities_area)

heatmaply(normalize(ammenities_mat),
          Colv = NA,
          dist_method = "euclidean",
          hclust_method = "ward.D",
          seriate = "OLO",
          colors = Blues,
          k_row = 8,
          margins = c(NA, 200, 60, NA),
          fontsize_row = 4,
          fontsize_col = 5,
          main = "Geographic Segmentation of Singapore by ammenities available",
          xlab = "Types of Ammenity",
          ylab = "Planning Subzone"
          )











Reveal Code
groups <- as.factor(cutree(hclust_ward, k = 10))

ammenities_sf_cluster <- cbind(ammenities_area_sf, as.matrix(groups)) %>%
  rename(`CLUSTER`=`as.matrix.groups.`)





Lastly, this section will give the user a geographical visualisation of the clustering pattern of ammenities in Singapore based on the number of clusters selected.
tm_mouse_coordinates()


Reveal Code
tmap_mode("view")

tmap_options(main.title = "Ammenity Clusters of Singapore", check.and.fix = TRUE)

tm_shape(ammenities_sf_cluster) +
  tm_polygons("CLUSTER", alpha = 0.3) + 
tm_basemap("OpenStreetMap") +
tm_scale_bar() +
tm_mouse_coordinates()






Reveal Code
tmap_mode("plot")

title: Take-Home Exercise 3: Prototyping geospatial segmentation module for analysis of accessibility in Singapore
text:
Here, we compute the number of each ammenity found in each planning subzone of Singapore using st_intersects() and lengths() functions, and compile them into a single sf object using bind_cols().


Reveal Code
hawker_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, hawker_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

mrt_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, mrt_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

school_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, school_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

supermarket_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, supermarket_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

mall_count <- st_intersects(sg_area_sf, mall_sf) %>% 
  lengths()

ammenities_area_sf <- sg_area_sf %>% 
  bind_cols(hawker_count = hawker_count, 
            mrt_count = mrt_count, 
            school_count = school_count,
            supermarket_count = supermarket_count,
            mall_count = mall_count)

ammenities_area_sf


Simple feature collection with 55 features and 6 fields
Geometry type: GEOMETRY
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM

We drop the geometric properties of the ammenities sf object here using st_drop_geometry() for use in computation functions later on.


Reveal Code
ammenities_area <- ammenities_area_sf %>% 
  st_drop_geometry()





The correlational table between the ammenity counts are computed and visualised here using cor() and corrplot.mixed() respectively.


Reveal Code
cluster_vars <- ammenities_area
  
cluster_vars <- cluster_vars %>% 
  column_to_rownames("PLN_AREA_N")

cluster_vars.corr = cor(cluster_vars)

corrplot.mixed(cluster_vars.corr, 
               lower = "ellipse", 
               upper = "number",
               tl.pos = "lt",
               diag = "l",
               tl.col = "black")

text:
In this section, we explore the possibility and usefulness of standardising the ammenity counts either via a Min-Max method, or a Z-score method.




Reveal Code
ammenities_area.std <- cluster_vars %>% 
  normalize()

describe(ammenities_area.std)

Reveal Code
raw <- ammenities_area %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mrt_count)) + 
  geom_density(color="black",
               fill="light blue") +
  ggtitle("Raw values without standardisation")

min_max <- as.data.frame(ammenities_area.std) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = mrt_count)) + 
  geom_density(color="black",
               fill="light blue") +
  ggtitle("Min-Max Standardisation")

z_score <- as.data.frame(ammenities_area.z) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=mrt_count)) +
  geom_density(color="black",
               fill="light blue") +
  ggtitle("Z-score Standardisation")

          ncol = 3,
          nrow = 1)

title: Take-Home Exercise 3: Prototyping geospatial segmentation module for analysis of accessibility in Singapore
text:
In this section, we conduct an analysis into the clustering options that we have for our data set. This involves both the number of clusters to impose on the data set as well as how to assign the planning subzones of Singapore to each cluster.




Reveal Code
proxmat <- dist(cluster_vars, method = 'euclidean')
glimpse(proxmat)


 'dist' Named num [1:1485] 56.4 14.6 37.7 12.3 51 ...
 - attr(*, "Size")= int 55
 - attr(*, "Labels")= chr [1:55] "ANG MO KIO" "BEDOK" "BISHAN" "BOON LAY" ...
 - attr(*, "Diag")= logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "Upper")= logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "method")= chr "euclidean"
 - attr(*, "call")= language dist(x = cluster_vars, method = "euclidean")







Reveal Code
hclust_ward <- hclust(proxmat, method = 'ward.D')
plot(hclust_ward, cex = 0.6)














Reveal Code
m <- c( "average", "single", "complete", "ward")
names(m) <- c( "average", "single", "complete", "ward")

ac <- function(x) {
  agnes(cluster_vars, method = x)$ac
}

map_dbl(m, ac)


  average    single  complete      ward 
0.9156607 0.7370762 0.9384262 0.9751807 







Reveal Code
set.seed(3414)

gap_stat <- clusGap(cluster_vars, 
                    FUN = hcut, 
                    nstart = 25, 
                    K.max = 10, 
                    B = 50)

print(gap_stat, method = "firstmax")


Clustering Gap statistic ["clusGap"] from call:
clusGap(x = cluster_vars, FUNcluster = hcut, K.max = 10, B = 50, nstart = 25)
B=50 simulated reference sets, k = 1..10; spaceH0="scaledPCA"
 --> Number of clusters (method 'firstmax'): 10
          logW   E.logW       gap     SE.sim
 [1,] 6.023155 6.215061 0.1919060 0.06033639
 [2,] 5.367560 5.794513 0.4269525 0.04005712
 [3,] 5.126679 5.626705 0.5000260 0.03467222
 [4,] 5.013784 5.522581 0.5087969 0.03428329
 [5,] 4.920985 5.434568 0.5135828 0.03458648
 [6,] 4.745587 5.358681 0.6130945 0.03699720
 [7,] 4.649645 5.289783 0.6401384 0.03830743
 [8,] 4.543042 5.226270 0.6832276 0.03989880
 [9,] 4.440743 5.165790 0.7250475 0.04174360
[10,] 4.322139 5.108704 0.7865646 0.04191712




After computation of the Gap-statistics, we can visualise the results via the fviz_gap_stat() function. From the graph drawn, we could use either 8 or 10 clusters in our algorithm as they are quite similar in effectiveness in capturing the clustering patterns of ammenity options across Singapore. Lesser clusters like 7 or 5 might be possible but not optimal. For the rest of this analysis, 8 shall be used as it is more parsimonious than 10 whilst having an indistinguishable Gap statistic.


Reveal Code
fviz_gap_stat(gap_stat)

title: Take-Home Exercise 3: Prototyping geospatial segmentation module for analysis of accessibility in Singapore
text:
Reveal Code
plot(hclust_ward, cex = 0.6)

rect.hclust(hclust_ward, 
            k = 8, 
            border = 2:5)














Reveal Code
ammenities_mat <- data.matrix(ammenities)

heatmaply(normalize(ammenities_mat),
          Colv = NA,
          dist_method = "euclidean",
          hclust_method = "ward.D",
          seriate = "OLO",
          colors = Blues,
          k_row = 8,
          margins = c(NA, 200, 60, NA),
          fontsize_row = 4,
          fontsize_col = 5,
          main = "Geographic Segmentation of Singapore by ammenities available",
          xlab = "Types of Ammenity",
          ylab = "Planning Subzone"
          )











Reveal Code
groups <- as.factor(cutree(hclust_ward, k = 8))

ammenities_sf_cluster <- cbind(ammenities_sf, as.matrix(groups)) %>%
  rename(`CLUSTER`=`as.matrix.groups.`)







Reveal Code
qtm(ammenities_sf_cluster, "CLUSTER") + 
  tm_layout(main.title = "Ammenity Clusters of Singapore") + 
  tm_compass(type = "rose") +
  tm_scale_bar()

title: Take-Home Exercise 3: Prototyping geospatial segmentation module for analysis of accessibility in Singapore
text:
In this section, we shall outline how the UI design will work. The main selectable variable here will be the number of clusters used in the clustering algorithm. For the purpose of this demonstration, 8 shall be the default as it is the optimal number computed using Gap-statistics as a measure. Other selectables to be included are the parts of Singapore to be analysed, the used of planning zone types (i.e. subzone, region etc.) and the types of ammenities to be investigated.


Here we will produce the cluster dendrogram with each cluster highlighted based on the requested number of clusters selected from above.


Reveal Code
plot(hclust_ward, cex = 0.6)

rect.hclust(hclust_ward, 
            k = 10, 
            border = 2:5)












Like above, the following UI will demonstrate how the clustering mechanism works based on a requested number of clusters selected. Additionally, options to apply different standardisation options will be included. Here, standardisation via Z-score is used for the demonstration.


Reveal Code
ammenities_mat <- data.matrix(ammenities_area)

heatmaply(normalize(ammenities_mat),
          Colv = NA,
          dist_method = "euclidean",
          hclust_method = "ward.D",
          seriate = "OLO",
          colors = Blues,
          k_row = 8,
          margins = c(NA, 200, 60, NA),
          fontsize_row = 4,
          fontsize_col = 5,
          main = "Geographic Segmentation of Singapore by ammenities available",
          xlab = "Types of Ammenity",
          ylab = "Planning Subzone"
          )











Reveal Code
groups <- as.factor(cutree(hclust_ward, k = 10))

ammenities_sf_cluster <- cbind(ammenities_area_sf, as.matrix(groups)) %>%
  rename(`CLUSTER`=`as.matrix.groups.`)





Lastly, this section will give the user a geographical visualisation of the clustering pattern of ammenities in Singapore based on the number of clusters selected.
tm_mouse_coordinates()


Reveal Code
tmap_mode("view")

tmap_options(main.title = "Ammenity Clusters of Singapore", check.and.fix = TRUE)

tm_shape(ammenities_sf_cluster) +
  tm_polygons("CLUSTER", alpha = 0.3) + 
tm_basemap("OpenStreetMap") +
tm_scale_bar() +
tm_mouse_coordinates()






Reveal Code
tmap_mode("plot")

title: In-Class Exercise 10: Modelling Geographical Accessibility using Hansen’s Method
section: Modeling the geographical accessibility using the Hansen method
text:
Modeling the geographical accessibility using the Hansen method

Computing the Hansen accessibility statistic


Reveal Code
acc_Hansen <- data.frame(ac(hexagons$demand,
                            eldercare$capacity,
                            distmat_km, 
                            #d0 = 50,
                            power = 2, 
                            family = "Hansen"))

colnames(acc_Hansen) <- "accHansen"

hexagon_Hansen <- bind_cols(hexagons, acc_Hansen)

title: In-Class Exercise 10: Modelling Geographical Accessibility using Hansen’s Method
text:
Visualising the computed Hansen’s accessibility

Hansen’s Accessibility Statistic


Reveal Code
mapex <- st_bbox(hexagons)

tmap_mode("plot")

tm_shape(hexagon_Hansen,
         bbox = mapex) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accHansen",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(eldercare) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to eldercare: Hansen method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)











Distribution of Hansen’s Accessibility Statistic


Reveal Code
hexagon_Hansen <- st_join(hexagon_Hansen, mpsz, 
                          join = st_intersects)

ggplot(data=hexagon_Hansen, 
       aes(y = log(accHansen), 
           x= REGION_N)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary", 
             fun.y="mean", 
             colour ="red", 
             size=2)

dbcTRIPS <- as.data.frame(dbcSIM$fitted.values) %>%
  round(digits = 0) %>% 
  rename(dbcTRIPS = "dbcSIM$fitted.values")

  cbind(uncTRIPS, orcTRIPS, decTRIPS, dbcTRIPS)

title: In-Class Exercise 11: Spatial Interactive Modelling
section: Modeling the geographical accessibility using the Hansen method
text:
Modeling the geographical accessibility using the Hansen method

Computing the Hansen accessibility statistic


Reveal Code
acc_Hansen <- data.frame(ac(hexagons$demand,
                            eldercare$capacity,
                            distmat_km, 
                            #d0 = 50,
                            power = 2, 
                            family = "Hansen"))

colnames(acc_Hansen) <- "accHansen"

hexagon_Hansen <- bind_cols(hexagons, acc_Hansen)

title: In-Class Exercise 11: Spatial Interactive Modelling
text:
Visualising the computed Hansen’s accessibility

Hansen’s Accessibility Statistic


Reveal Code
mapex <- st_bbox(hexagons)

tmap_mode("plot")

tm_shape(hexagon_Hansen,
         bbox = mapex) + 
  tm_fill(col = "accHansen",
          n = 10,
          style = "quantile",
          border.col = "black",
          border.lwd = 1) +
tm_shape(eldercare) +
  tm_symbols(size = 0.1) +
  tm_layout(main.title = "Accessibility to eldercare: Hansen method",
            main.title.position = "center",
            main.title.size = 2,
            legend.outside = FALSE,
            legend.height = 0.45, 
            legend.width = 3.0,
            legend.format = list(digits = 6),
            legend.position = c("right", "top"),
            frame = TRUE) +
  tm_compass(type="8star", size = 2) +
  tm_scale_bar(width = 0.15) +
  tm_grid(lwd = 0.1, alpha = 0.5)











Distribution of Hansen’s Accessibility Statistic


Reveal Code
hexagon_Hansen <- st_join(hexagon_Hansen, mpsz, 
                          join = st_intersects)

ggplot(data=hexagon_Hansen, 
       aes(y = log(accHansen), 
           x= REGION_N)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  geom_point(stat="summary", 
             fun.y="mean", 
             colour ="red", 
             size=2)
